revision:
1. If a natural number \(m\) can be expressed as \(n^3\), where \(n\) is also a natural number, then \(m\) is a cube number. In other words, a natural number obtained when a number is multiplied by itself three times are known as cube numbers. These numbers are also called perfect cubes.
  2. Properties of Cube Numbers :
    • If a number has \(1\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(1\).
    • If a number has \(2\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(8\).
    • If a number has \(3\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(7\).
    • If a number has \(4\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(4\).
    • If a number has \(5\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(5\).
    • If a number has \(6\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(6\).
    • If a number has \(7\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(8\).
    • If a number has \(8\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(2\).
    • If a number has \(9\) in the unit's place, then it's cube ends in \(9\).
    • Cubes of even numbers are always even and cubes of odd numbers are always odd.
  3. The cube of a number \(n\) is equal to a unique set of \(n\) consecutive odd natural numbers.
  4. In the prime factorisation of a cube number, each factor appears thrice.
  5. The cube root of a given natural number \(m\) is that number which when multiplied by itself three times gives \(m\) as the product and we denote the cube root of \(m\) by \(\sqrt[3]{m}\). Thus, \(\sqrt[3]{m}=n \Rightarrow m=n^3\). Cube root is the inverse operation of cube.
  6. In order to find the cube root of a perfect cube, resolve it into prime factors; make groups of 3 of the same factors and take the product of prime factors, choosing one out of every group.
